captions.text: The Baltic Sea...

See how calm it is on
such a quiet, peaceful night.

And yet it is
a battlefield for people,

who armed and
armoured their ships.
This is one such ship.

We'd like to show you her adventures
during the early weeks of the last war.

It will not be, however,
a reconstruction
of historical events.

Even though our ship is called
Orzeł and the movie

was partially based on
her real adventures.

The people we show here
are not portraIt's of Orzeł's crew.

One should not seek
in them actual people.
We intend to show a part of the human lot

in the severe conditions
of military service at sea
during a war.
ORZEŁ
screenplay
director
camera
design

One can almost see
one's own house.

You're talking like a civilian,
do you regret it?

- Do I regret what?
- Our poor Navy,

- how will it make it without you?
- Leave me alone.

No fear, losers are needed
also in civilian life.

- Baczek.
- Yes, sir.

What are the duties of
a marshaller on duty?

The Marshaller on duty should concentrate
his attention on his duties.
Exactly.

- What's up?
- Peace, quiet.
Daydreaming?
So are you getting married or not?

- Obstacles again?
- Not again, one
and the same...

- Commodore...
- Don't you know him?

Seamen should not
get married at all.

You know what?
He just might be right.
What did you mean by that, sir?

- What is it, Okoń?
- A falling star, sir.

- So what?
- You should think of a wish

- and it will come true.
- What is the duty of a marshaller?

- Yes, sir!
- Right.

- Coffee! Fresh coffee!
- Finally!
Listen, how do you do it...

- It's simple.
- Show me.
Try.
Look away, magician!
Do you want to bet?

- Leave me alone.
- Who else wants coffee?

Give me some of that
mocha of yours.

- What is it?
- Rhinoceros.

- Haven't you seen a dog?
- On a submarine?

- Is it yours?
- Mine, aren't we two alike?

Just wait till the commodore sees it,
you will see.

What did you take
that dog for?
Take? It followed me to the port.

What was I supposed to do,
drown it?

When it meets our boat-swain...
You're dead and buried.

So far it hasn't so
it shouldn't happen tomorrow.
Just don't give it any sausage.

Naturally,
It's sausage from Żywiec.
Hey you! Don't eat my fingers!

Beautiful night,
visibility as if during the day.
The day will break very soon.

In such weather we should see
the lights on the coast very clearly.

Indeed...
Ustka should be somewhere there.

It is but there are no lights,
It's weird...
What do you find weird, lieutenant?
I can't see any lights, sir.

- Excuse me.
- And what is your conclusion?
Blackout.
Common, decent people sleep there

as they should at this time of night,
that's all.

- Bridge!
- Control room!

- Lieutenant Morawski!
- Lieutenant Morawski!

- Lieutenant Morawski speaking.
- Give me our position.

54 degrees 47 minutes North,
16 degrees 50 minutes East.

- We are abeam Ustka.
- What?
Ust... Stolpminde.

Ah, Stolpminde. Please,
use the names on our maps.
That will be all.

War psychosis,
the high command is also going crazy.

They are laying mines in the bay,
have you ever heard about any such thing?

Yes, sectors 3 and 5,
naturally, I did.
Control room!

- Bridge, lieutenant Pilecki.
- Inform the commodore

that Mirta receives Berlin.
Hitler's speech in Reichstag.

- Lieutenant Morawski, sir.
- I heard it, some bullshit again.
Let's go.
Which is why I decided

to answer Poland
in the same language,

that Poland has
used for months.

And from now we shall pay
with a bomb for each bomb!

I hope that the matter of an
absolute obedience to regulations

in the face of the enemy
is obvious to everybody.
Each offence must be punished.

Heads of sections will
carry out an inspection.

- Boatswain Pierzchała?
- Yes, sir.

Boatswain Pierzchała is responsible
for order on the whole boat.
Yes, sir...

Boatswain Bryt will
inspect the torpedoes.

Everything clear?
Any questions?
What is it, Mirta?
I would like to ask a question, sir,
it all happened so suddenly...
Be brief, Mirta.

I would like to ask, sir,
whether our boat will enter the port and...

- we will see our families?
- Families? Now?

The command of the garrison
will look after the families.

One must forget about
personal matters, Mirta.

Any more questions?
None? Thank you.
Lieutenant Roland...

Even during a war you
should button up your uniform.

That is what they're for,
Don't forget about it.

- Who do you have in Gdynia, Mirta?
- Wife, sir.
And why are you worried?

Before we left the port,
I drove her to the hospital.

- Anything serious?
- Labour, she was very much afraid.

It's our first, sir.
She's not that young.

Everything will be fine.
There's no reason to worry.

Maybe it's over already
and we have a new citizen?

Well, you won't need
that any time soon.

Fold and put away,
next...

- What is it, Rokosz?
- I beg to report, sir,

- It's a button.
- And where should this button be?
I beg to report, sir,

- that I don't know, It's not mine.
- Are you mocking me, Rokosz?

I beg to report, sir, that
I'm not missing any buttons.

- And what is it?
- A button, sir.

- And this?
- May I?
Well...

- I can't see any buttons here.
- What do you do in the navy, Rokosz?

You should perform at village fairs.
Is it yours?
Yes, sir.

What now? Hocus-pocus
and there will be order, well...
You're a lousy magician, Rokosz.

Stop showing off, Rokosz.
No more jokes.

What did I say, Rokosz?
Go to hell!

- It wasn't me, sir.
- And who else? A priest from Oksywie?

I beg to report, sir...
It's a dog.
Well... tiger would be better.

Enough of these jokes!
What is it supposed to mean?!
You're quite a trouble-maker.

- Where are we?
- Here, we're making an arch.

So what do you think
about this war?

I wish we could sink
a cruiser for starters.

- That would be something, wouldn't it?
- You're a dreamer, lieutenant.

Cruisers don't sail on their own.
I would be satisfied with

one of the smaller
dogs that guard it.
Lieutenant Morawski must shave.

Three hairs were seen
on the southern slopes of his chin.

- Surfacing.
- Yes, sir.

- Empty central ballast tanks.
- Surfacing! Empty tanks!

Check if the report for
the command has been sent.

- It's the bridge, calling on radio!
- Radio, roger.

- Was the report for the command sent?
- The command does not respond.
I maintain constant radio watch.

The Schleswig-Holstein
is shelling Westerplatte.

- Maybe we could come closer?
- Mines everywhere.
Airplanes on port!
They're heading for Gdynia.
Scoundrels, bombing the city centre.
Torpedo boat on the starboard!

- From the command.
- Finally.
Airplane port 40!

- Air-raid warning!
- Air-raid warning!
Air-raid warning!

Plane 60, port 70!
Open fire!

One third speed ahead,
25 degrees to starboard.

- Helm amidships!
- Helm amidships!

50 to starboard, 40 airplane!
Open fire!
Airplanes to starboard!

- Cease fire, everybody down!
- Cease fire, 40 down!

- Emergency submersion!
- Emergency submersion!

- There are people up there, sir!
- They should have gone down long ago.
And so should you.

Well... what's up, cannoneer?
When it's time to shoot

you hide under water,
Don't you?
If you were there, sir,

the planes would stand no chance.
You're such a sharp-shooter.

You've gone too far, Rokosz,
you spoilt brat.

- Leave me alone!
- Calm down, Rokosz! Get lost!

- Why are you picking on him?
- I will show you.
It's not going to end like this.

Certainly, a junior sailor must
respect an older boatswain.

I won't let anybody make a fool out me,
don't even dream of it.

- A dog can tell a good man.
- The dog will have to be sorted out as well!

Do you see what you've done?
Now we're both screwed.

- Dog? What dog?
- Dog, dachshund.

Ah, that one. So what about
the dog, does it bother you?
Not me, but if the commodore...

I don't think that the commodore has
the time for dogs at the moment.
My thoughts exactly, sir...
just so... excuse me.

- What's the story?
- Nothing much.

A dog followed Baczek to the port
and they took it along.

And you told him it was the
commodore's dog?

I only said that the commodore
wouldn't have time for such trivialities.
Here it is... the fourth one!

- What is it, engineer?
- We keep on going back and forth.

- Waiting for orders.
- And nothing? And there, maybe...

But... they may have problems
with the radio station, anyway

- there must be some disorder at the beginning.
- Some? It's not the way I thought

- it would be.
- Neither did I...

Oh, tell the boss I must
charge the batteries.
Will do.

- Any contact?
- Maybe when we resurface, sir.

Lieutenant Roland wants
to charge the batteries.

- He will have enough time, you...
- Yes, sir?

- Is radio antenna up?
- All the time.

- Who's on duty?
- Boatswain Mirta.

Oh, him, he thinks only
about his family all the time.
Everyone left someone on land, sir.
And so did you, I know.
Haven't you, sir?

Why do you ask?
What kind of question is this?

You cannot tell private matters
from the official ones, lieutenant.

How can it be that we can't
communicate with the command!
We keep constant radio watch, sir.

We're surfacing.
Steer on Gdynia.

- Periscope down. Surfacing.
- Surfacing.
Control room!

- Bridge here.
- Cable from the command.
Cable from the command, sir.
Let's go.

- A part of the text is missing, sir.
- I see.

Entry to port temporarily closed.
What does it mean: temporarily?

We are to go on a patrol
in the Gulf of Finland.

- We have no contact again.
- The command is under fire.

- You're ill, sir.
- It doesn't matter.

We're going to
the boarder of sector 8

and keep on trying to
communicate with the command.
And I will lie down for half an hour.

- I'll assist you, sir.
- Thank you.

If anything happens,
report immediately.

- What's happened to him?
- I have no idea.

You think it was your home but
it could've been three streets away.

- I saw it.
- Come on...
What could you see from here?

The whole port is covered by smoke,
you can see nothing.

But when the wind blew,
one could see houses in the city.
But not in this part.

They couldn't destroy all Gdynia
in a couple of hours.

Can you stop babbling now?
You go on and on like old wives.

Why so nervous?
You see? He can't sleep.
Now the day is for sleeping.
We're at war, civilian.

Hush, Pirate!
Go to your kennel!

Leave him alone, he must have
something important to tell us.
Be quiet!
Let's see what else you've done.

- Did you see it?
- I did, dog licked your face.
Dogs can tell good people.

Go to sleep and check
on the commodore.

- Combat alert!
- Combat alert!

- Submerging 40 meters!
- Submerging 40!

- Submerging 40!
- Trim minus 5.

Location 35.
Location 30. Location 30.

- Both engines stop. Silence on the boat.
- Both stop. Silence on the boat.
Silence, bloody hell!

Location 40.
Location 35. Location 35.

Location permanent.
Location permanent.
Stop!

- What am I to stop, bombs...
- The hiccup, they can hear you in Konigsberg!

Control room, lieutenant Pilecki.
Captain Grabiński? Yes, sir!

Location 120.
Location 118. Location 118.

- What happened?
- The commander calls for you. An attack, I guess.

- Location permanent. Location permanent.
- Send Morawski.
Look away! Mine!
Location 30.

Two are leaving.
I can't hear the third one.

- Both motors slow ahead.
- Both motors slow ahead.
Finally.

Did you get anxious, civilian?
You can get hit on land as well.

I'd rather it happened on land
than in this coffin.
It's only for the time being...
What can this be, bloody hell?

Today, at 12.30, Mr. Coulondre,
French ambassador in Berlin,

delivered ultimatum
to minister Ribbentrop,
the deadline of which passed at 5 p.m.

As a result of lack of a reaction
Great Britain and France declared war on

- the German Reich.
- Calm down, silence!

We have repeated
the special communique.

Attention! Attention! Coming!
Attention! Attention! Coming!

Comma three passed!
Comma three passed!
How are you today, sir?

Bad.
Sit down, please.

- What news?
- Bad.
Well...

- Westerplatte has capitulated.
- How long did it last?

- Seven days.
- Well...

- What else?
- Germans approaching Warsaw.

- You heard it from them?
- No, it's a communique of the High Command.

- Any orders?
- We are to stay in the Gulf of Finland.

- Task?
- Sink enemy ships

- and expect further orders.
- You're not very good at this sinking.

- Make me an injection.
- The pains don't go away?
Please, agree, sir.

We could approach one
of the neutral ports at night.

- You want to get rid of me.
- You're poisoning yourself with this morphine.

- Captain Grabiński over.
- Can you come now to the conning tower?
Just a moment.

What are you waiting for?
Do you want me to go there?
The right engine is down.
Anything serious?
Will you manage on your own?

Add this to the report.
If it's quiet go up to periscope depth.
I will be with the commodore.
Things change for the better.

- Just for now, it'll get worse.
- Stop looking on the dark side!

- Your nerves are not what they used to be either.
- And stop thinking about my nerves,

- only about your engines.
- OK, OK.

- Remember to report to the command.
- I will when I can get through.
If I can't, I won't.
Conning tower speaking.

International maritime law
allows entering a neutral port

- for 24 hours.
- Save me all these lectures

- in maritime law, I know it well enough.
- I know you do, sir.

But at the moment your illness
is no longer our only problem.

We have a malfunctioning engine
and we need to repair it.

- Yes?
- we received an order from the command, sir.
What is it?

We are to enter Tallinn to seek
medical assistance for you, sir.

And replace the broken
bearing in the engine.

Our naval attache has
already been notified.

- What else?
- That's all, sir.
Are you satisfied?

Calm down! Attention! Tomorrow
in the morning all must wear.

- their mess dresses and be shaved. Clear?
- What is it, Maciek?

- We are entering Tallinn.
- Seriously?

The first good news
since the war began.

You have reached your goal, captain.
I'm going ashore.

It's a good boat,
look after her.

How did the commodore take
the decision about his surgery?

He is not aware of anything,
he was hardly conscious.
Anyway, you should leave tomorrow.

- And leave him behind?
- There is nothing you can do.

- Have you called me?
- How is that bearing, engineer?
We're almost done.

- I just wanted to make sure.
- But we still haven't gotten the promised fuel.

- They haven't provided it yet?
- Well, they have not.
I'll see to it presently.

It'd be good, as you know
we're in a bit of a hurry.

Well, well, I will make
some calls from the embassy.
Is there anything else, sir?
No, you're excused.
Wiktorczyk, don't switch it on!

Bloody hell!
Who told you to switch on the engines?!

- I just wanted...
- I told you to wait, bloody hell!

You have destroyed our last bearing.
What shall we do now?

- Can we make another?
- Make? How? With what?

Shit! What are you staring at?!
Dismantle everything!

- What was that?
- We're screwed.

I don't know if the harbour
master will see you now.

But I spoke to you just
a few minutes ago and you?

Please, sit down.
I'll see what I can do.

Polish attache, sir.
Yes.

Commodore Hozer?
I'll put you through.

The Harbour master begs your
forgiveness but he is very busy.

His deputy, commodore Hozer,
will see you.
Take your seats, gentlemen.

- Captain Grabiński from Orzeł.
- Welcome.

I am sorry that we have not been
able to deliver fuel for Orzeł,
but Schwerin had priority.

They'll finish the repairs tomorrow
and in the morning.

What do you mean?
You do know that we must leave
at six a.m. at the latest.
Unfortunately, it won't be possible.
But it's very important for us.
That's really good.
Very important, I see.

The German ship would
be a nice prey for you.
Schwerin leaves the port at 5 a.m. so
What is the connection with Orzeł?
Do I really have to explain?

The connection is that
Orzeł may leave the port

no sooner than 24 hours
after Schwerin.

So that you would not be able to
catch up with her and bang!

Torpedo her.
Is it clear?

But we may stay in Tallinn
only for 24 hours.
Not at all, it is an exceptional situation.

We'll get you ready to
leave by 5 p.m. tomorrow.

We'll provide you with
fuel, water, food,

and everything else
you might need.

And we will wish you
a happy journey
and happy hunting. Agreed?

In such circumstances, sir,
we give up the fuel.
We're leaving.

I see. And you will wait for
Schwerin somewhere near.
Please, confess.

You must understand
that in our situation,

Germans will blame us
for the loss of their ship.
No, captain, I wish you all the best,
but it's impossible.

So as I've just said, Orzeł will get
fuel tomorrow in the morning

and it may sail at 5 p.m.
Agreed?

You can sleep peacefully, gentlemen,
we'll get everything done on time.

- Anything new?
- This gunboat won't leave us alone.

It doesn't matter.
Oh, skipper asks for codes.

- A cable?
- I don't know.
Come in.

- You asked for the codes, sir.
- I did, thank you.

If there is anything that
must be coded, I'll gladly...

- No, there is nothing at the moment. That will be all.
- Yes, sir.
What are you doing there, Rokosz?
What is it?
I beg to report, sir, It's Pirate.

It doesn't look like a pirate to me.
Is it yours?

- Actually... mine, sir.
- You do know the regulations.

It was only for the time being, sir.
I thought we would...

I see but now all our
life jackets are in danger.

Not all, sir. Only...
boatswain Pierzchała's.
Why Pierzchała's of all people?

- They don't like each other.
- Who?

- Boatswain Pierzchała and Pirate.
- And why is it so?

Boatswain Pierzchała says that
Pirate should be thrown into the sea

- because of regulations, sir.
- He says so but doesn't do it.

- Actually, he did not...
- So...

You must watch that... Pirate of yours
so that it does no excessive damage.

Yes, sir!
Thank you, sir.
You see... you walking disaster.
Well.

- Any news about our fuel?
- Call the embassy.

- Remind them about a tugboat and pilot.
- Will do.
Call captain Grabiński.

- Are you the commander?
- I am his deputy.

I have received orders
to intern the boat.

- Intern?
- Yes, sir.
The Harbour master made a promise, sir.
The Harbour master has changed his mind.
I cannot accept it.
Your boat must leave the port by six.

- It's a deceit.
- You can call it what you want.

- I will do everything, sir!
- Be reasonable.

Believe me.
It is not a pleasant mission for me.
We both have no other choice, captain.

In our situation we
must not risk a conflict.

We are very sorry.
Such an unexpected accident!

Lieutenant, please,
switch off the fan.

Well done.
We can move on.

I believe the lieutenant has
taken care of everything.
The Polish crew will remain aboard,
And the Estonian High Command

guarantees Poles
equal rights to those of
Estonian seamen.

On condition of signing
a declaration of loyalty.

The boat will be disarmed and will
remain in Tallinn until the end of the war.

The declarations must be submitted
to the skipper within 24 hours.
Lower the flag.
Admiral.
Please, wait, lieutenant.
OK.
Lieutenant Morawski.
Lower the flag.
About turn!
Attention!
Lower the flag!
This is Polish Radio Warsaw.

We are broadcasting the communique
of the Command of Defense of Warsaw.

The enemy launched tonight an attack on Praga
which was repulsed with much bloodshed
regardless of heavy enemy shelling.
The enemy air force continues

to bomb the city, destroying
in the process numerous historical buildings,

churches and hospitals.
The population of the city
staunchly defends the capital

regardless of the 8 days of bombing,
lack of water, electricity,
food and drugs.
Something went wrong at Mirta's.

- Or maybe it was in Warsaw?
- What kind of war is this?

The government ran away, the High Command ran away,
and we're supposed to risk our heads for them.

You're right, what for? You'll be
safe and sound here until the end of the war.

- And you won't?
- Me? No.

You're going on holidays, aren't you?
The war is over.

It depends for whom.
It isn't for Warsaw.

And our destroyers Grom and
Burza are already in England.

Did you hear that? He's heading for England.
With our Orzeł?

- Maybe with Orzeł.
- Get real.

Do you know what it would take to get
to England across the whole Baltic sea?

They would sink us ten times, man,
even before we could leave the port.

- Is this what you think, Bryt?
- What else, sir?

You haven't fired a single shot, and...
It's not quite right.

- Did you see this tough guy?
- Stinkers.

Leave it.
Let them worry.

Are you out of your mind?
Hit yourself on the head with this hammer.
It takes a hammer.

Apparently, you should
never touch a decent gun.

- You idiot.
- Yes, but...

Laugh, laugh, you kipper.
It takes intelligence, not strength.

You see?
This is the way to do it.
You see, African stinker?
Mr. Pole, give it back right now.

I don't understand,
speak some human language.
Please, give it back right now.
Search me, you fool.

Give it back to him, Rokosz.
We won't  gain anything this way.
But it's the bolt, sir.

- Give it back to him, Rokosz.
- But I don't have it, sir,

- cross my heart.
- So what happened to it?

It's in the other
fool's right pocket.

The bolt is in this sailor's pocket.
Please, check it.
Check your pockets.
I give my word of honour, sir, that...

Do you see, you idiot?
And he accuses honest Polish seamen.

Enough of that.
Help them with the torpedoes.

What? We are to help
them rob Orzeł?
They're taking our fuel.

Done, sir, you just need to explain
that they must position

Orzeł with her bow towards the exit

Yes, you're right,
there is no other way.
Ready!
Ready!

- Look away!
- Stop!

Okoń! We don't have
a spare one, do we?
How could we, sir?

We need not just
the cable but also clamps.
Time off, boys!

They even write here that
we will be able to go back

- to our homes.
- Well, that's after the end

- of military operations.
- Which means how long more?

- Two weeks, no more than a month.
- Well, but there will be an occupation.

Occupation... wasn't there
an occupation during the previous war?

People coped somehow.
What else can we do?

- Are we to go to a camp for POWs?
- In Warsaw they are going to fight

and I am expected to sign that I am out of it.
Shit! I'm not signing any declaration.

If you don't, they'll lock you in a camp

- Lock me? Just a moment...
- My words exactly, let's run till we can.

I guess so. Up theirs
with the declarations.

Are you mad?
Where will you run to?

- Where? To England.
- To England? Without fuel, without maps?
We still have enough fuel, fear not.

- Look at that, our civilian got mobilized.
- Stop calling me a civilian, will you?
I am a bosun's mate to you, kid.

And if you want to, you can rot here
but we won't give in so easily, do you follow?

Did you hear that? They won't give in.
They will shoot with peas.

Our boatswain will be shooting
with peas on his neutral diet.

- We still have some torpedoes.
- Boatswain Pierzchała will take torpedoes

Leave Pierzchała alone, snotty kid!

Commissioned officers and seamen who intend

- Bridge
- I'm here!

- Ready, sir!
- Coming!

Baczek, telephone the coast.

- Look away, don't break the cable!
- Yes, sir!

- We're ready.
- Go to fore.

- Both engines ready.
- Switch on both.
Wiktorczyk! Okon! Faster!

- Right now!

- Faster, holy cow!
- Go down right now!

I'm coming!
Go now, sir!

- Right engine two ahead.
- Two ahead.

- Port 10.
- Port 10.

Pull!
Try harder!
We got him!

Holy crap!
We're stuck.
Both engines stop!

- Both stop.
- Slow astern.
Slow astern.
Smoke screen!

- Both stop!

- Switch on Diesel engines!

- Slow astern!
- Slow astern!
Both stop!

- Both third ahead!
- Both third ahead!

- Port 10!

+Voinar010 To co napisałeś na temat Orła to trochę półprawdy. Fakt był 
dobrze uzbrojony i dysponował sporą prędkością nawodną, ale to nieprawda, 
że Niemcy się go bali. Fakt i to  mogę potwierdzić, że zgodnie z hiptezami 
nasza flota podowdna była przygotowywana do konfrontacji z sowietami oraz 
neutralizacji ich pancerników/ Odnosząc się do sytuacji i knfrontacji z 
Niemcami to III Rzesza nie była  brana pod uwagę jako wroga, aż do 1936 
roku. 3 lata to zbyt mało czasu by mogli sie przygotować. Były dobre plany 
użycia polskich op przeciw Niemcom, jak chociażby obstawienie Zatoki 
Pomorskiej, ale Niemcy to nie takie głupki i w swoich planach przewidywali 
to też. Powiedziałbym więcej, czytając relacje z zajść w porcie Helskim 
odniosłem wrażenie, że to właśnie Polacy się bali. I wcale się temu nie 
dziwię nasze okręty podowdne były bezbronne wobec małych jednostek tak samo 
jak wobec lotnictwa.

Chciałbym zwrócić uwagę że twórcy na samym początku filmu wypowiedzią 
lektora wyraźnie zaznacza że to jest film fabularny inspirowany jedynie 
historią, a bohaterowie "to nie portrety załogi Orła". Moim zdaniem twórcy 
podeszli tutaj do sprawy bardzo uczciwie, zwłaszcza w porównaniu z innymi 
filmami czy ludźmi dyskutującymi o historii którzy swoją interpretację 
przedstawiają jakby to była "prawda objawiona" albo przynajmniej że film 
"jest oparty na faktach" podczas gdy spora część to fikcja
